description: From a fusion of Middle English swam (â€œswamp, muddy pool, bog, marshâ€, also â€œfungus, mushroomâ€), from Old English swamm (â€œmushroom, fungus, spongeâ€), and Middle English sompe (â€œmarsh, morassâ€), from Middle Dutch somp, sump (â€œmarsh, swampâ€), or Middle Low German sump (â€œmarsh, swampâ€), from Old Saxon *sump (â€œswamp, marshâ€); all from Proto-Germanic *sumpaz.

Related to sump, swim.

entries.meaning: A piece of wet, spongy land; low ground saturated with water; soft, wet ground which may have a growth of certain kinds of trees, but is unfit for agricultural or pastoral purposes.
A type of wetland that stretches for vast distances, and is home to many creatures which have adapted specifically to that environment.
(figurative) A place or situation that is foul or where progress is difficult.

verbs.description: swamp (third-person singular simple present swamps, present participle swamping, simple past and past participle swamped)

entries.meaning: To drench or fill with water.
examples: The boat was swamped in the storm.

entries.meaning: (figurative) To overwhelm; to make too busy, or overrun the capacity of.
examples: I have been swamped with paperwork ever since they started using the new system.

entries.meaning: (figurative) To plunge into difficulties and perils; to overwhelm; to ruin; to wreck.
examples: The Whig majority of the house of Lords was swamped by the creation of twelve Tory peers.
